What a great story, game play is good but the story and visual effects are where this game is at. Glad I took the dive to try it and was hooked.

Love this game

That one of the most beatiful game I've played so far,

Bom Jogo recomendo muito

Voila je me suis lancé et j'ai acheté bioshock infinite (a un pris très raisonnable de 8€ avec les 2 premiers opus )Je tient tout d'abord a dire que je n'ai pas finit ce jeu et que je n'ai que 10h pour le moment .Ce jeu est juste une merveille en termes de graphisme ,de gameplay et d'histoire . Les graphismes sont très bon voir magnifique quand on a la chance de pouvoir faire tourner le jeu en ultra comme moi mais aussi en faible . L'univers est fantastique grace a des graphismes magiques et a un jeu très bien optimisé . Ensuite le gameplay est exelent ,les phases de combats sont intenses , une IA plutot bonne et des toniques très interressant qui donnent plusieurs styles de combats. Et pour finir l'histoire qui est énormissime avec des perrsonnage très vivant et très recherché (Elisabeth ou les 2 jumaux ) l'histoire et profonde intelligente avec une bonne dose de frissons et d'action . 
En gros se jeu est un condensé de perfection qui rendent l'experience inoubliable .
Pour finir je vous direz d'acheter ce jeu car il est extraordinaire !
Masterpiece.

Fantastic game. One of my favorite games of all time, and in my opinion, better than BioShock 1 and MUCH better than BioShock 2.
Now. I know that you're sharpening your pitchforks and lighting your torches. But don't. BioShock Infinite is a FANTASTIC game. It combines the BEST of BioShock 1 and BioShock 2 to make a fantastic game. The combat elements of BioShock 2, being able to use Vigors(Plasmids) while also using your weapons. This is great, because I no longer have to swap between the two every ten seconds like in BioShock 1.
BioShock Infinite's story is also GREAT, and I can't spoil it. If you haven't played it yet, do it. The story will be one of the best you'll see in years.
Buy it. 
As for the DLC:
I have not played Burial at Sea, nor Clash in The Clouds. I do know that Burial at Sea is supposed to be the next Minerva's Den (10/10 BioShock 2 DLC) while Clash in The Clouds is just a horde mode with Elizabeth, your sidekick who can bend the fabric of reality.
Semplicemente fantastico!
Wow, just wow.
Отличный сюжет, отличный графон, отличная атмосфера!

Cool abilities, cute graphics.
I can't believe I never even finished the campaign.

7.5/10 Would rip time apart again.
SUPERGOOOOOD

Increible, casi tan bueno como el primero, aunque se centra mas en la accion. Tiene un arte y una narrativa impresionante. Ir con Elizabeth por las calles de Colombia es como ir con Alyx por Ciudad 17: no es simplemente un monigote que se dedica a disparar y a decir frases "molonas"....no, parece que tiene vida.
Solo veo 2 pegas: los graficos, que no es que fueran nada de otro mundo y aun asi no me iban bien en el ordenador; y el final: bueno esto en realidad le da un tono serio, pero a mi me habria gustado ver otro tipo de final, mas...feliz.
Me gusto mas el 1, pero este, como decirlo: si Bioshock fuera padre y tuviera como hijo a este, el Infinite, podria estar orgulloso( luego el Bioshock 2 seria mas bien su hijo drogadicto o su hermano criminal, pero eso ya es otra cosa)
Le daria un 9.4.
P.D.: lo del gancho fue un puntazo
Hoje o almoço vai ser lasanha
Très bon fps solo
This game is a 10/10. Amazing storyline, graphics, and action. Although I'm new to the FPS world, it was still such an amazing game to play. All the positive reviews are true.

This is one of the better games to come out in years, and my favorite of the franchise. It isn't without its faults, it could have used the stealth mechanics they ham-fistedly crammed into the second half of the DLC, and certain aspects of its story (Daisy and the Revolution) could have used a hell of a lot more polish. Overall though, it's a wild ride and an affecting story. I would recommend it to anyone who can stomach the violence, though I would skip the DLC.

soso

This game fucking sucks. The only good thing about this game is the story because it details the relationship between Booker and Elizabeth and involves all kinds of cool science shit like quantum particles and multiple dimensions. But it is not worth playing through this game to get it. The supposed "vigors" don't make it any better. Yeah they give you an advantage over enemies but other then that a lot of the time this game consists of the same boring and tedious pattern. Which is, get a gun, shoot guys, get on grappling hook, use Elizabeth for items etc. I wouldn't have an issue with this game if their was more variety, but I can't say their is. It hurts too because the story in this game is cinematic like a good movie, engaging, endearing, and captivating and intriguing. But overall, with the same thing being done gameplay wise over, and over, and over, and over, it just feels like a $20.00 slog more then a satisfying game. And excuse my lack of hours on here, I've played it a bunch on console and beaten it before and I think that grants me enough qualification to bomb on this game for what it is, a boring shooter.

Apesar da steam contabilizar 0.1 Horas, eu terminei a campanha inteira off por isso a falta de horas, mas tirando isso, Bioshock Infinite tem uma historia muito cativante com um final surpreendente, com easter eggs interessantes para fans da série Bioshock, e com enemies muito fortes, a unica falta q eu tenho de inimigos são os Big Dad, q foram substituidos por Hand Mans q são nada mais q personagens com deficiencia q tiveram uma segunda macabra chance de se mover e viver uma vida como guardas, os inimigos especiais contam tambem com pessoas q tomaram plasmideos e tem 1 dos poderes q o personagem principal (Buck Dewitt) pode adquirir, tais como ataque de corvos, fogo entre outros. Com a nova mecanica de movimentos mais fluidos q os jogos anteriores (o qfoi muito expressivos, baseado no segundo jogo, em q vc é um big dad), a parte mais lgl, concerteza é os trilhos aereos q vc ultiliza na maioria do jogo, é tao versatil e facil de ultilizar q vc cria inumeras chances de contra atacar inimigos q em um comfronto mano a mano seria impossivel, com um arsenal vasto e com a nova mecanica de apenas carregar 2 armas por vez( diferente de seus antecessores q vc adquiria até 9 armas em seu arsenal para sua caminhada no fundo de rapture). 
Muitas coisas q gostaria de contar para vcs, mas o melhor concerteza é jogar e descobrir cada deliciosa parte do jogo.
Bellissimo, il migliore dei 3 ovviamente !!!

Bir oyun en fazla ne kadar harika olabilir? sorusunun cevabı bu oyun abi.
Gerek atmosferi gerek senaryosuyla mükemmel bir oyun. Oyunu ilk çıktığı zaman görmüştüm resimlerinden çok hoşuma gitmişti ancak hiç alıp oynacak vakit bulamamıştım. Böyle bir harikayı geç oynadığım için üzüldüm ama oynayıp bitirdiğim içinde çok mutluyum. Ahh o Elizabeth yok mu! Ne de güzel yapmışlar hatunu vallaha hayran kaldım :D
Neyse uzatmaya gerek yok kısaca en üstte yazdığım sorunun cevabı niteliğinde bir oyun o yüzden hala almamış olanlar hemen alın pişman olmayacağınız nadir oyunlardan.

[b]«- Букер, ты боишься Бога?
- Нет,  но тебя боюсь.
- А боишься Пророка?
- Нет, с ним я разберусь» [/b]

[u][i]© Александр Сидман[/i][/u]

[h1]«Город святых»[/h1]

Среди лучей солнечного света,
И лёгких, белоснежных облаков,
Парит в небе чудо света,
Священный город без грехов.

И общество в нём тоже идеально,
У людей цвет кожи, словно снег,
И выражаясь фигурально,
Чем белее кожа, тем святее человек.

И там народом управлял святой Пророк,
Чью дочку охранял охранник страшный,
И лучше выдумать Пророк не мог,
Чем спрятать девушку в высокой башне.

И паству Он свою предостерёг,
Что в город поднимается Лжепастырь,
Чтоб народ святого Агнца уберёг,
От боли, лжи, страданий и несчастья.

Вот так ирония внезапная, увы,
Не каждый тут смог бы догадаться,
Ведь Лжепастырем являлись Вы,
И Вам с Пророком надо разобраться.

Летящий город рухнул, быстро пал,
А у Пророка голова слетела с плеч,
Ведь правильно Иисус в Писании сказал:
«Не мир Я Вам принёс, но меч!»

I'm in two minds about this game (an unintended pun).

On the one hand, I like the combat, the design, the clever hints at what's to come. On the other, it isn't really Bioshock, it feels like it's building up to something that never happens, and there's a lot of sections where you just watch things play out instead of actually playing them.

The other Bioshock games were about the player finding themselves in the aftermath of 'science gone wrong'. You wander about, collecting Plasmids/ADAM/EVE/Guns, fight off the deranged, mutated remnants of society, and try to avoid getting a Big Daddy arm through the chest.

This game puts you in before anything has gone wrong, and then your presence makes it go wrong. You spend the rest of the game with things going wrong and that's it. You don't get to wander around what you've done after it's happened. You never get the same feeling of loneliness or fear that Bioshock gave. You're in the middle of a civil war and getting shot at by both sides all the time.

There's also the problem of character development. Usually, a game is great when characters are fully worked out. But in this, it feels weird. You're playing a guy saying things you weren't thinking of saying, or not even agreeing with. They're telling you what you should be feeling, instead of letting you soak it up from others. I never got caught up in the whole Booker/Elizabeth thing, so she just came off as an annoying character you can't shake off. Where Half-life 2 succeeded, Bioshock 3 seemed to struggle.

Even the names of things are just replaced. Plasmids are now 'Vigours'. EVE is now 'salts'. ADAM is gone entirely, relying instead on coins for all upgrades. And no hacking machines, you just get to temporarily turn them to your side. It felt like they were making a game and relying entirely on the success of Bioshock to market it. It really should have been called 'Physhock', because it really is about physics over biology, and is based in an entirely different world to Rapture.

There also comes a point where you only really need a Hand-cannon and the Bucking Bronco vigour for the little enemies. Throw them in the air and them pick them off one by one. Even the Patriots aren't much if you can just keep shooting then ducking behind cover. The only time you need to keep your wits about you is when a Handyman appears. Those things soak up damage like it's going out of style. And they're fast. Faster than you are.

But despite that, it holds up. If they had just not tried to piggyback on Bioshock, I'd probably not have any criticism of it. It's a good game. The ending feels like it fizzles out a bit but other than that the gameplay is good. It keeps you entertained. Well worth a purchase, though I wouldn't say £20 is it's worth. A 75% off sale (which seems to be a regular occurence for Bioshock in the sale periods) would suit it nicely.
Just play it and experience an amazing world unfold.

"Bring us the girl, wipe away the debt. "

Bioshock Infinite is one hell of a ride... The game is a masterpiece in my opinion and is a game anyone should play. ANYONE. The story is extrmely interesting and the gameplay is fun as well. Though, the game is a bit short. I could finish it in seven and a half hours. 

The gameplay focuses on the shooting which is very good, there are a small variety of guns and you can only carry any two at a time. The fighting really comes out when you start to use vigors. What are vigors? They are these powers you can aquire through machines or bottles all throughout the world. They give you an extra edge in a fight and makes it stand out from most other FPS games out there. 

The story... Ooooh, the story. Holy hell. All I can say is that you if you play games for the story and such, play this. It has a great one which left me astonished and amazed at the end of the game. If you are lucky and haven't had the story spoiled for you, get it and just play. Hell, even if it has been spoiled, play it anyone, it is a ton of fun.

The characters in the game are rather lovable- Well, it's really just your character, Booker, and his companion, Elizabeth. But you start to feel a bond as you go through the game, getting more and more attached tot he characters which only seems to make the game all the more fun. 

Oh, and did I mention that you don't even need to take care of Elizabeth when you're fighting and she even throws you salts [ In a sense, mana for your vigors ], health, ammo, and even money? It's like a giant escort missionw here the escort can handle themselves and they even help you out. She doesn't fight though, BUT STILL. It takes a loud off your shoulders knowing that you don't even have to protect her in intense fights.

Overall, I would definitely recommend this game to anyone. The story is great, the scenary and map is beautiful, the gameplay is amazing. It's just a brilliant game. Get it.

the ending alone made me fall in love best bioshock game i have ever played. i did not think i would like the game play but i was wrong fast.

Very very fun game. One of if not THE best story I've ever had the pleasure to play through, and visually pleasing. Lots of variety in scenery and overall feel. A very welcome departure from your traditional FPS. A good mix of stealth-based (or not, you can totally just go in there guns blazing) combat and story-driven gameplay. The expansion packs add a good substory to it, however having not ever played Bioshock 1 I felt like I was missing a good many references. Like fake laughing at a joke that was a little funny to you, but funnier to everyone else who were present for the story behind it. Very well-made, no glitches or bugs that come to mind. The cornerpiece of this particular game, however, is the story. It truly is a masterpiece. *mini spoilers* When you start this game, you may think you have some inkling of how it will end. Listen to me carefully. You have absolutely no idea what you are in for. Accept it. I paced my room for a good seven to ten minutes just contemplating the ending, trying to figure it out. As a Star Trek fan, I am no stranger to paradoxes and causal loops and alternate realities, but this is on another level entirely. Mind-blowingly elegant.

My only complain is that some parts of the game got really fraustrating. Like the safes and the second and the third cipher. other than that It was an awesome game. awesome atmosphere legit story legit backstory legit connection 9/10

I have always been fascinated by this series. There is always a twist in the game events that you would never expect. The DLCs elaborate on this connection and give you a taste of the past. Totally love it and would recommend it.

This is an absolute 10/10 game. This game offers the most beautiful world I've played in so far and tbf I was a bit worried about the gameplay, but that turned out to be very intuitive and you get the hang of it very fast. The story also really blew me away. Ken Levine is one of the greatest storytellers and game creators of our age.

If you can make a story that can keep you genuinely puzzled in a way that makes Inception look like child's play, if you can make a single player campaign this extensive, though not an element too much, if you can make a world look so amazing up to the greatest details including the easter eggs and create a lore around it that seems to be pretty watertight (haven't really found any plotholes so far)...

The only part that I didn't find enjoyable was the 'The Atrium' with the Boys of Silence (I didn't know yet that you could avoid them) level and I literally only had a bug 1 time in an entire playthrough where Elizabeth got stuck.

10 out of 10, guys. This game reached a stellar status in my book on my first day of playing it.

10\10

[i]Bioshock Infinite[/i] is a good game. Damn good. But there are a lot of things about it that holds it back from being one of last generation's most definitive FPS games.

For starters, it's a standard two-weapon inventory shooter. It has a few issues inherent to this style in that you're forced to tediously pick up new weapons every few moments. For [i]Infinite[/i], this felt restrictive and unnecessary. Vigors, while bog standard in utility and imagination, are okay, but forgettable. I found myself making use of weapons far more than the Vigors, never feeling encouraged to make them a core part of my game plan. The weapon and vigor upgrades also never felt like they amounted to anything worthwhile. Different outfits/clothing items also give you different buffs, but don't really enhance a formula that's little more than "get gun, get ammo, hit enemies." The raw gunplay itself at least feels competent, but given the original [i]Bioshock[/i]'s diversity of approaches and options, [i]Infinite[/i]'s overall gameplay feels like a step backwards.

This wouldn't be a problem if the game didn't emphasize action at the expense of the world-building. Booker and Elizabeth have worthwhile conversations and there are a lot of great dystopian themes at work, but the focus on run-of-the-mill quality gunfights really stifled the way this world came to life. The game shoves dystopian commentary in your face (in the spirit of the series) and many of the world's themes and politics (e.g. Jim Crow, intense nationalism, religious fanaticism) come from some of the most toxic corners of American history and culture. Modern players could have a relevant personal or moral stake in the game's universe, but the lack of any meaningful choices or directions to take bars you from feeling like you're a compelling part of the world.

The game actually does do a great job with world-building in the early game and I absolutely praise how well these worlds are first presented. Like the iconic descent sequence into the original [i]Bioshock[/i]'s Rapture, your ascent to Columbia is borderline heavenly. Its blue skies, lively colors, and active populace mirror Rapture's dim, deteriorating setting. It makes it all the more heartbreaking that the game revolves around average gunplay and drawn-out action sequences, preventing players from establishing a better relationship with Columbia.

I will also give the game credit for being pretty and running well. I ran this on a laptop from 2011 (i7-2000 series, Mobility Radeon 6570) and while I couldn't run it on maximum settings, I could still fully appreciate what they've done. The Sky-Line system is also exhilarating, albeit underused, and the voice acting's spot-on. For all of the game's faults, I still had a good time. It just wasn't a special time.

If [i]Infinite[/i] took some lessons from the Deus Ex School of Game Design (e.g. hub worlds for pacing, side quests for organic world-building, being able to make decisions that actually matter)... or even just the first two [i]Bioshock[/i] games, [i]Bioshock Infinite[/i] could have been something truly spectacular. It didn't have play like generic shooters, especially since it's plausible that people would look to this series to get away from those. Instead, it's a prettier version of what we've already seen and felt in other shooters, but without actually playing much better than them.

I don't think I can really recommend [i]Bioshock Infinite[/i] to the same extent of its praise at launch, especially considering that we now live in a world with [i]Wolfenstein: The New Order[/i] (a campy yet sophisticated alt-history slaughterfest that excels in high-octane action, flexible playstyles, and great worldbuilding. In essence, a game that fulfills its commitment to its mechanics and its setting without sacrificing one for the other.) If you walk into [i]Infinite[/i] with the same expectations you have for average-at-best shooters, you'll be fine. It's a good romp through an intriguing world and worth playing once.

But the problem is that this is [i]Bioshock[/i], and my expectations for [i]Bioshock[/i] are far higher than my expectations for other shooters. Yours should be, too.

IMO the best of the shock series, at least the latest run of them. More challenging and engaging gunplay than Bioshock 1 and 2, and a really, honestly excellent story. Somehow Elizabeth just grabs you, and I found myself caught up in the plot in a way that video gaming usually doesnt manage.

9.5/10 - A Journey through the clouds

Futuristic, fps, third installment of Bioshock. Amazing Graphics and gameplay. Everything is so masterfully crafted. Unfortunately, this game has a low replay value since everything remains vivid in your mind. 

Worth the cash!

In terms of gameplay mechanics and the single player experience, Bioshock Infinite is one of those incredibly great games that every gamer has to experience. It’s exceedingly rare for video games to handle such serious themes like racism, xenophobia, and religious fanaticism, but to do so in a satisfying narrative that is both illuminative and, well, fun, makes [i]Infinite[/i] truly stand out amongst the rest. 

As entertainment, it is top notch. As social commentary, it promotes discourse. As a game, it’s fun.

Excelente historia y buena jugabilidad

I didn't really enjoy the other Bioshock games that much. For some reason, this is the first game in the series that was enjoyable to me. The gameplay, story, visuals and characters are great. Combat is satisfying and versatile, although I keep wishing that I was allowed to carry one or two more weapons, as you are allowed to carry one primary and one secondary weapon. The plot got quite woolly near the end, but overall it was a great experience.
I don't know why I bought more than one BioShock game.  I get bored of being on rails pretty quickly...
